Name: Intent–Structure Decomposer
Purpose: Decompose scenarios into causal, intentional, and relational components to classify whether harms are intended vs foreseen, actions vs omissions, and means vs side effects, then provide a common structural description usable by both utilitarian and deontological evaluators
Deliverables: A formal representation of the trolley scenario that: (1) distinguishes causal chains (what causes what) from decision nodes (what the agent controls); (2) tags each harm as intended, chosen as a means, or merely foreseen side effect, using counterfactual and goal-analysis tests; (3) marks whether each morally salient outcome results from commission or omission, and whether the omission involves a failure of a role-based duty; (4) outputs a neutral structural map (graphs + tagged propositions) that can be fed into utilitarian outcome-calculators (ignoring intent tags) and deontological rule-checkers (focusing on intent, means/side-effect, and action/omission distinctions); (5) offers equivalence and non-equivalence classifications between variants of the trolley problem (e.g., switch vs footbridge) based on these structural features
Strengths: Good at: (a) clarifying whether lever-pulling constitutes using the one person as a means or imposing a side-effect risk; (b) making disputes about intent and action/inaction precise rather than rhetorical; (c) revealing when two cases differ only in framing vs when they differ in underlying causal/intentional structure; (d) enabling common ground by separating factual/structural disagreements from purely normative ones, so both utilitarian and deontological agents can work from the same structural description
Watch-out: Breaks down when: (a) intentions are underdetermined or agents have mixed/opaque motives that resist clean classification; (b) the environment is too complex to yield a tractable causal graph, leading to arbitrary simplifications; (c) moral relevance of certain structural distinctions (e.g., fine-grained degrees of foreseeability) is contested and the framework forces a coarse binary; (d) the mapping from structural tags (e.g., ‘foreseen side effect’) to normative import is assumed rather than left to downstream moral theories, causing hidden bias toward one framework
